questions.text: A patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus experiences hypoglycemia and sustains a fall. Due to incoherent speech, a CT scan is performed and reveals a substantial subdural hematoma (SDH) with a volume greater than 30 cc. What should be the immediate next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Stabilize the patient and urgently seek a neurosurgical consultation

questions.explanation:
Feature

Acute SDH

Chronic SDH

Timing

0-72 hours

>3 weeks

Clinical Features
  • Rapid deterioration
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Focal deficits
  • High mortality
  • Gradual onset
  • Confusion
  • Headache
  • Gait disturbance
  • Better prognosis

Risk Factors
  • Severe trauma
  • Young adults
  • Coagulopathy
  • Elderly
  • Brain atrophy
  • Anticoagulation
  • Minor trauma

CT Findings
  • Hyperdense crescent
  • Immediate mass effect
  • Hypodense/mixed density
  • Bilateral in 20-30%
  • Gradual mass effect

Management
  • Emergency craniotomy
  • Reverse coagulopathy
  • ICU care
  • Burr hole drainage
  • Hold anticoagulation
  • May observe small ones

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed the following rhythm. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Ventricular Fibrillation

Asystole

Ventricular Tachycardia

Pulseless Electrical Activity

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation (Option A)

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (Option C) (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Immediate Recognition

Identify Non-Shockable Rhythm: Recognize asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA).

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓
Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓
Establish intravenous or intraosseous lines for medication administration.

↓
Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Administer IV/IO after the first 2 minutes of CPR.

↓

Identify Rhythm

  • Non-Shockable Rhythm: Continue CPR and administer epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.

Goal: To increase the likelihood of developing a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is necessary for effective defibrillation.

  • Shockable Rhythm: Administer a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

↓
Advanced Airway Management

Airway: Secure the airway with endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation for adequate oxygenation.

↓
Continue CPR

Resume chest compressions for 2 minutes.

↓
Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Primary Focus: Address reversible causes, especially hypothermia.

↓
Repeat CPR and Epinephrine

Cycle: Continue repeating CPR and epinephrine administration every 3-5 minutes.

questions.text: All of the following is used in the management of breathless patients at a high altitude of 3000 mts except.
The recommended temperature of a water bath for a patient with frostbite is
According to the ABCD2 scoring, which factors indicate a greater likelihood of a patient with TIA experiencing a future stroke?

options.label: B

questions.text: During a scorching summer afternoon, a man, who had been toiling in a field, unexpectedly collapsed. Upon examination, there were no apparent physical indications of dehydration, although his radial pulse was detectable. The doctor determined that the man's serum electrolyte levels were within the normal range. Shockingly, the man's body temperature measured 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Considering these circumstances, which of the following should be administered as an initial form of immediate assistance?
questions.correct_answer: C. Cover with cool damp sheets
questions.explanation:
Condition

Heat Exhaustion

Heat Stroke

Cause

Prolonged strenuous activity with inadequate water/salt intake in a hot environment.

Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure (Option C ruled out).

Symptoms

Nausea, vomiting, malaise, myalgia

Sudden collapse and loss of consciousness.

 

CNS symptoms: dizziness, fatigue, impaired judgment, psychosis (severe water depletion)

Skin initially wet, then dry

 

Moist skin, increased pulse

Hyperventilation, tachycardia.

 

Rectal temperature > 37.8°C

Core temp > 40.5°C

 

 

Other symptoms such as Constricted pupils, convulsions, unconsciousness, cerebral dysfunction, high fever, absence of sweating.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of frostbite is incorrect?

options.label: D
options.text: The area is dried and cleaned

questions.correct_answer: C. Antibiotics and analgesics not used
questions.explanation:
Cause

Symptoms

Treatment

Exposure to extreme cold (-2.5ºC), causing tissue freezing and blood supply obstruction

Blue-black discoloration of fingers, toes, nose, ears, face.

  • Mild cases: numbness, prickling.
  • Severe cases: paresthesia, stiffness, necrosis, gangrene, edema, blisters.
  • Rewarming:
    • For superficial frostbite (frostnip): Firm steady pressure is applied with a warm hand (without rubbing), by placing fingers in the armpits and for the feet, by covering with dry socks
    • For deep frostbite: Frozen extremity is immersed for several minutes in a moving water bath, heated to 40–42°C, until the distal tip of the part being thawed, flushes
  • Pressure or friction is avoided
  • Anti-infective measures: Tetanus prophylaxis and antibiotics for deep infection

questions.text: A patient was being treated in ICU for sepsis. The initial ABG shows pH= 6.9, pO 2 = 80 mm Hg. pCO 2 = 55 mmHg, HCO 3 = 10 meq/L. A repeat ABG after 2 hours shows pH=7.1, pCO 2 = 20 mmHg, pO 2 = 140 mm Hg, and HCO 3 = 10 meq/L. Which is most plausible to explain the change seen in the ABG report?

options.label: A
options.text: Excessive air and less heparin in the ABG sample

options.label: B
options.text: Excess air and more heparin in the ABG sample

options.label: C
options.text: Less air and more heparin in the ABG sample

options.label: D
options.text: Less air and less heparin in the ABG sample

questions.correct_answer: B. Excess air and more heparin in the ABG sample

questions.text: What medication can be administered to a patient who experiences altered consciousness, sweating, rapid heartbeat, persistent erection, and increased saliva production, with a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mm Hg after visiting a temple with their grandmother?

A patient presents to the ER with anaphylaxis; which of the following not a part of the clinical criteria to diagnose anaphylaxis? Urticaria, edema of the lips and tongue, and rashes within 2 minutes to 2 hours of contact. Wheeze and respiratory distress Abdominal cramps and vomiting Hypertension
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - 3 and 4

questions.text: In a post-operative patient, after 2 hours of receiving FFP, sudden onset dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachypnea, hypotension, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray occur. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - TRALI (Transfusion-related acute lung injury)

questions.text: What is the lifelong treatment for individuals who have received a potent prosthetic mitral valve replacement?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - W

questions.text: A farmer has come with symptoms of pinpoint pupils, excessive salivation, and increased secretion from the body. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Organophosphate poisoning

Muscarinic effects

Nicotinic effects
  • D – Diarrhea (increased GI motility, Bowel sounds)
  • U - Increased frequency of Urination
  • M - Miosis pupil
  • B-Bradycardia (by activation of M2 receptors)
  • B-Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm
  • E - Emesis
  • L-Increased Lacrimation
  • Red tears or chromodacryorrhea is seen due to secretion of porphyrin in tears
  • L - Lethargy
  • S – Salivation
  • Headache, tremor, confusion slurred speech, coma, convulsions.
  • Initially, it causes muscle fasciculations, areflexia.
  • Later, muscle paralysis occurs (Type-1 or Acute syndrome).
  • Death occurs due to paralysis of respiratory muscles (i.e respiratory failure).

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with necrotizing fascitis was admitted to the ER. The patient was tachycardic and hypotensive. He was treated for septic shock. Which of the following is the characteristic feature of refractory septic shock?

options.label: A
options.text: Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration

options.label: B
options.text: Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration and high dose vasopressors

options.label: C
options.text: Shock that is refractory to medical treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Shock that does not improve despite treatment for 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: B. Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration and high dose vasopressors
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Shock persisting > 1 hour after IVF administration and high-dose v

questions.text: Which test is the most sensitive for diagnosing Organophosphate poisoning among the following options?
questions.explanation: Correct option A - Plasma acetylcholinesterase:

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate was >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Check blood sugar lev

questions.text: Which of the following is not done before drawing blood for arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Flexion
